leaflet.page_1: Package leaflet: information for the user. ASPIRIN C, 400 mg + 240 mg, effervescent tablets. Acetylsalicylic acid + Ascorbic acid. Please read this leaflet carefully before taking this medicine because it contains important information for you. Always take this medicine exactly as described in this leaflet or as advised by your doctor or pharmacist. Table of contents: 1. What Aspirin C is and what it is used for, 2. What you need to know before you take Aspirin C, 3. How to take Aspirin C, 4. Possible side effects, 5. How to store Aspirin C, 6. Contents of the pack and other information.
leaflet.page_2: 1. What Aspirin C is and what it is used for. Aspirin C contains acetylsalicylic acid (pain-relieving, anti-inflammatory, antipyretic action) and vitamin C (beneficial during colds). Indications: symptomatic treatment of mild to moderate pain (e.g. headache, toothache, muscle pain), and symptomatic treatment of pain and fever in cold and flu.
leaflet.page_3: 2. What you need to know before you take Aspirin C. Do not take: if allergic to active substances or other salicylates, if you have a bleeding disorder, active stomach or duodenal ulcer, severe heart/liver/kidney failure, asthma induced by salicylates, if taking methotrexate ≥15 mg/week, in the last trimester of pregnancy, or in children under 12 years. Warnings: hypersensitivity to NSAIDs, concomitant anticoagulant use, liver/kidney disorders, peptic ulcer disease, glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency, breastfeeding, risk of Reye’s syndrome in children. Aspirin C may cause bronchospasm and allergic reactions.
leaflet.page_4: 2. Continued information. Aspirin C and other medicines: increases the effects of methotrexate, anticoagulants, corticosteroids, digoxin, antidiabetic medicines, valproic acid, SSRIs. Reduces the effect of gout medicines, diuretics and some antihypertensives. Alcohol increases the risk of side effects. Pregnancy and breastfeeding: contraindicated in the 3rd trimester, in the 1st and 2nd trimester only if necessary, not without medical advice. Passes in small amounts into breast milk. May temporarily reduce female fertility.
leaflet.page_5: 3. How to take Aspirin C. Always use as described in this leaflet or by your doctor. Adults: 1–2 effervescent tablets at a time, every 4–8 hours; maximum 8 tablets/day. Adolescents >12 years only on doctor’s advice: 1 tablet every 4–8 hours; maximum 3 tablets/day. Dissolve in water and drink after meals. Do not use longer than 3–5 days without consulting a doctor. Overdose: may cause poisoning (ringing in the ears, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, breathing disorders, bleeding, neurological disorders, coma). In case of overdose seek medical advice immediately. Treatment: gastric lavage, activated charcoal, alkaline diuresis, hemodialysis.
leaflet.page_6: 4. Possible side effects. Like all medicines, Aspirin C can cause side effects. Serious symptoms requiring immediate medical attention: coffee-ground vomiting, black stools, swelling of face/tongue/throat, difficulty breathing, asthma, anaphylactic shock. Most common: stomach pain, heartburn, nausea, vomiting, indigestion, gastrointestinal bleeding, peptic ulcer, dizziness, ringing in ears. Less common: liver disorders, allergic reactions, bronchial asthma, prolonged bleeding time, thrombocytopenia, haemolysis in patients with G6PD deficiency, kidney failure, cerebral hemorrhage.
leaflet.page_7: 5. How to store Aspirin C. Store below 25°C, keep out of the reach of children. Do not use after the expiry date. Do not dispose via wastewater or household waste. Ask your pharmacist how to dispose of medicines. 6. Contents of the pack and other information. Composition: active substances – acetylsalicylic acid and vitamin C; excipients – anhydrous sodium citrate, sodium bicarbonate, anhydrous citric acid, anhydrous sodium carbonate. Appearance: white effervescent tablets in sachets, packs of 10 or 20. Marketing authorisation holder: Bayer Sp. z o.o., Warsaw. Manufacturer: Bayer Bitterfeld GmbH, Germany. Date of last revision: January 2019.
